title: When China Won’t Play Ball
text:
Editor’s note: This Future View is about China’s spat with the National Basketball Association and the league’s response. Next week we’ll ask about U.S. foreign policy: “Is President Trump an isolationist? An Obama-style ‘realist’? Or something else entirely?” Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Oct. 22. The best responses will be published that night.

Not ‘Inappropriate’ at All

The tweet that enraged the Chinese government, “Fight for Freedom. Stand with Hong Kong,” is one the National Basketball Association should celebrate. Instead, the NBA apologized for the tweet’s author, Houston Rockets General Manager Daryl Morey. In its Oct. 7 Chinese-language statement, the league declared itself “extremely disappointed” in Mr. Morey’s “inappropriate comments.”

In what America is an expression of support for democracy—an appeal for solidarity with courageous people protesting an oppressive government—considered “inappropriate”? In the past, the NBA has acted differently. It supported athletes such as LeBron James, Kobe Bryant and Derrick Rose, who used their platforms as basketball players to support the Black Lives Matter movement, which is no stranger to controversy. “Political speech is an absolute right within the league,” Commissioner Adam Silver said last year. The NBA even pulled its 2017 all-star game out of Charlotte, N.C., due to the state’s transgender bathroom bill. The difference here is that the NBA worried that free speech critical of China could leave a dent in its business.

“ A company that takes a progressive stance on transgender bathrooms but acquiesces to a totalitarian regime that denies its 1.4 billion citizens fundamental human rights either has a twisted worldview or the backbone of a jellyfish. ”

A company that takes a progressive stance on transgender bathrooms but acquiesces to a totalitarian regime that denies its 1.4 billion citizens fundamental human rights either has a twisted worldview or the backbone of a jellyfish.

— Jessica Jakoby, Cornell Tech, computer science

What the NBA Did Right

As the general manager of the Houston Rockets, Daryl Morey should have thought hard before tweeting his support for the Hong Kong protests. Business executives must know that their words reflect on their organizations, and that getting embroiled in political or cultural fights can hurt the company and all those who rely on it. Since the Houston Rockets are particularly popular in China, it wasn’t hard to predict that Mr. Morey’s tweet would encounter intense backlash, risking the Rockets’ entire business in China.

Despite the widespread criticism, the National Basketball Association handled the resulting crisis appropriately. The league acknowledged that offending Chinese fans was “regrettable” but nevertheless defended the right of executives and athletes to speak their minds. After being pressed further, Commissioner Adam Silver clarified the league’s position: “We are not apologizing for Daryl exercising his freedom of expression.” The league has resisted Chinese pressure—Mr. Morey still has his job and Beijing remains without a formal apology.

The organizations that deserve criticism, however, are those that bend the knee to China’s economic might. Many Hollywood studios censor their movies for Chinese audiences; Mercedes-Benz has apologized for quoting the Dalai Lama; and Apple has removed the Taiwanese flag emoji from its keyboard in certain jurisdictions.

The NBA hasn’t done anything like that. Put in a difficult situation, it defended its interests without sacrificing core American values. Many other Western companies can learn from it.

— Eric Asen, Vanderbilt University, political science and economics

The NBA Can’t Have it Both Ways

The economic bullying and narcissistic sensitivity of the Chinese Communist Party is limited only by its victims’ prostration. Give the bullies an inch and they take a mile. They not only use American companies and technology to censor Chinese people, but also intimidate those same companies into condemning or censoring their own American employees.

“ As an American business, the NBA ought to be consistent. Stay standing or remain seated. ”

The National Basketball Association tried to satisfy everybody with its response to China’s boycott and ended up satisfying nobody. The league’s half-apology simply made it look bad. Everyone could tell the NBA was trying to have it both ways. It wanted to affirm the right to free speech while also telling its people to shut up and dribble—or compute statistics, in Mr. Morey’s case. As an American business, the NBA ought to be consistent. Stay standing or remain seated.

—Mack Meas, Northwestern University, M.B.A.

description: Students grade the NBA’s response to Beijing’s bullying.
